other/The-XY-problem.title: The XY problem
other/The-XY-problem.content:
is asking about your attempted solution rather than your actual problem
The problem occurs when people get stuck on what they believe is the solution and are unable step back and explain the issue in full.

playground.title: playground
playground.content:
import numpy as np
import torch
import torch.nn as nn
from torch.utils.data import TensorDataset, DataLoader
from sklearn.datasets import load_iris
from sklearn.decomposition import PCA
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
 
class AutoEncoder(torch.nn.Module):
    def __init__(self):
        super().__init__()
        self.encoder = torch.nn.Sequential(
            torch.nn.Linear(4, 2),
            torch.nn.ReLU(), # <-- Funktion variieren
            )
        self.decoder = torch.nn.Sequential(
            torch.nn.Linear(2, 4),
            torch.nn.ReLU(), # <-- Funktion variieren
            )
 
    def forward(self, x):
        encoded = self.encoder(x)
        decoded = self.decoder(encoded)
        return decoded
 
    
def main():
    # === Daten laden ===
    X, y = load_iris(return_X_y=True)
    #X = PCA(4).fit_transform(X) # <-- ein/aus kommentieren
    train = TensorDataset(torch.as_tensor(X, dtype=torch.float32))
    train_loader = DataLoader(train,
                              batch_size=16,  # <-- Zahl variieren
                              shuffle=True)
 
    
    # === Modell trainieren ===    
    model = AutoEncoder()
    loss_fun = nn.MSELoss()
    optimizer = torch.optim.SGD(model.parameters(),
                                lr = 0.004)  # <-- Zahl variieren
    print("initial encoder weights\n", model.encoder[0].weight.detach().numpy())
 
    epochs=20 # <-- Zahl variieren
    losses=[]
    for epoch in range(epochs):
        for sample in train_loader:
            reconstructed = model(sample[0])
            loss = loss_fun(reconstructed, sample[0])
            # recompute gradients:
            optimizer.zero_grad() # clean gradient cache
            loss.backward() # do backprop
            optimizer.step() # use gradient to learn
            losses.append(loss.detach().numpy())
 
 
    # === Ergebnisse angucken ===
    print("found encoder weights\n", model.encoder[0].weight.detach().numpy())
            
    # geht das in den folgenden zwei Zeilen nicht auch sch√∂ner?
    reconstruction = np.array([model(torch.tensor(x, dtype=torch.float32)).detach().numpy() for x in X])
    latents = np.array([model.encoder(torch.tensor(x, dtype=torch.float32)).detach().numpy() for x in X])
 
    # plot in X-PCA coordinates:
    pca = PCA(2).fit(X)
    X = pca.transform(X)
    reconstruction_ = pca.transform(reconstruction)
    reconstruction = PCA(2).fit_transform(reconstruction)
    
    fig, (ax1, ax2, ax3, ax4, ax5) = plt.subplots(5)
    ax1.scatter(X[:, 0], X[:, 1], c=y)
    ax1.set_title("Original data, first two PCs")
    ax2.scatter(reconstruction_[:, 0], reconstruction_[:, 1], c=y)
    ax2.set_title("Reconstruction, same projection ")
    ax3.scatter(reconstruction[:, 0], reconstruction[:, 1], c=y)
    ax3.set_title("Reconstruction, first two PCs")
    ax4.scatter(latents[:, 0], latents[:, 1], c=y) #XXX
#    ax4.scatter(latents[:, 0], np.zeros_like(latents[:,0]), c=y)
    ax4.set_title("Latent vectors")
    ax5.plot(losses)
    ax5.set_title("MSE Loss")
    plt.subplots_adjust(hspace=0.5)
    plt.show()
    
if(__name__ == "__main__"):
    main()
 
Transclude of iris-autoencoder.py
f x = x * 3 
main = do
  print (f(3))

rechnerarchitektur/CPU.title: CPU
rechnerarchitektur/CPU.content:
x86 architecture | x86 assembly
Von Neumann machine


strictly sequential processing

easy to program


instruction and data are stored in the main memory

compete access to the memory  \Rightarrow Possible bottleneck!



![[vonneumanncpu.png|300]]
Performance improvements?

Comman techniques

Increase the clock frequency
Increasing the cache size
Increasing the number of pipeline stages


Challenges

There are often situation points for these techniques, which limit performance gains.
And with increasingly complex architectures, not only the monetary cost for these techniques increase disproportionately.



Pipelining

= Concurrent execution of phases of an instruction
Example: 4-stage pipeline;

Only throughput is increased
Problem: conditional jumps
\rightarrow branch prediction
![[pipelining4stage.png|250]]



Extensions of the von Neumann Machine

Flynn defined four classifications for modern computer architectures Based on the number of concurrent instruction streams and data streams available

SISD: Single Instruction Single Data \Rightarrow von Neumann Machine
SIMD: Single Instruction Multiple Data
MISD: Multiple Instruction Single Data
MIMD: Multiple Instruction Multiple Data


Knows as Flynn‚Äôs taxonomy

Chip-Level Multi-processing

Reduction of 1% voltage and 1% frequency reduces the power consumption by 3% and the performance by 0.66%$


Simultaneous Multithreading / Hyperthreading

Processors are mostly waiting for the main memory or the I/O devices
Idea: Hardware emulates a second logical core

If the core has nothing to do, it is able to switch to another instruction stream




Assembly

x86
Error-prone!
why?:

context switch, interrupt handling, usage of special I/O instructions



rechnerarchitektur

rechnerarchitektur/CPU/MIMD.title: MIMD
rechnerarchitektur/CPU/MIMD.content:
MIMD: Multiple Instruction Multiple Data

Multiple instructions \Rightarrow multiple CPUs, which are able to compute multiple instruction streams
In principle, two design options:

CPUs doesn‚Äôt share the memory \Rightarrow also known as cluster
CPUs share the memory \Rightarrow multi-processor systems

rechnerarchitektur/CPU/MISD.title: MISD
rechnerarchitektur/CPU/MISD.content:
MISD: Multiple Instruction Single Data

Several CPUs process one data stream executing different instructions
Mainly for fault tolerance, e.g. flight computer in space shuttle

rechnerarchitektur/CPU/SIMD.title: SIMD
rechnerarchitektur/CPU/SIMD.content:
SIMD: Single Instruction Multiple Data

In principle, one instruction on a set of data \Rightarrow e.g. vector operations

rechnerarchitektur/CPU/x86.title: x86
rechnerarchitektur/CPU/x86.content:
Registers

only integers
16 general registers (64 bit)

RAX RBX RCX RDX RDI RSI RSP RBP
R8 R9 R10 R11 R12 R13 R14 R15


status registert (RFLAGS) (64 bit)
instruction pointer (RIP)(64 bit)
implicitly assigned registers:

RSP: stack pointer
RBP: base register
RCX: count register
RSI, RDI: (source / destination) index register

rechnerarchitektur/assembly/c-calling-co.title: c calling convention
rechnerarchitektur/assembly/c-calling-co.content:
x86 assembly | x86 architecture | CPU | wiki calling_conventions

Passing the first six arguments by register (System Call)

Afterwards the stack is used (Right-To-Left (RTL) order)


the function who polluted the stack has to clean it!

Example from ‚Äúhello world‚Äù to function call

Hello World using  int 0x80
call and ret using syscall
using stackframe

number doesn‚Äôt fit (of addition todo)
Add Stackframe visualization




in x86 (32bit) is stack used for arguments
other conventions

rechnerarchitektur/assembly/x86-examples.title: x86 examples
rechnerarchitektur/assembly/x86-examples.content:
CPU |  x86 | x86
first minimal
SECTION .text
 
; the destination of an instruction is always the left side
 
;load 42 into the register rax
mov rax, 42
 
; load 0 into the register rax
mov rbx, 0
 
; addition of op1 and op2, result is stored in op1 (left side) => e.g. rax = rax + rbx
add rax, rbx
 
; subtraction of op1 and op2, result is stored in op1 (left side) => e.g. rax = rax - rbx
sub rax, rbx
 
; unsigned multiply, rdx:rax = rax * op
mul rbx
 
; signed multiply, rdx:rax = rax * op => e.g. rdx:rax = rax * rbx
imul rbx
Hello Wold
SECTION .data
	msg: db "Hello World",10 ; the string to print, 10=cr
	len: equ 12 ; similar to #define in C
 
SECTION .text ; code section
 
global _start ; make label available to linker
 
_start: ; standard entry point
	mov rdx, len ; arg3, length of string to print
	mov rcx, msg ; arg2, pointer to string
	mov rbx, 1 ; arg1, file descriptor (stdout)
	mov rax, 4 ; sys_write syscall number
	int 0x80 ; fire system call
	mov rbx, 0 ; exit code, 0=normal
	mov rax, 1 ; exit command to kernel
	int 0x80 ; interrupt 80 hex, call kernel to exit process
function call using x86_64 ABI
SECTION .text       ; code section
 
global _start       ; make label available to linker
_start:             ; standard entry point
	mov rdi, 1      ; arg1, file descriptor (stdout)
	mov rsi, msg    ; arg2, pointer to string
	mov rdx, len    ; arg3, length of string to print
	call _my_func   ; push raddr on stack and jump to label my_func
	mov rbx, 0      ; exit code, 0=normal
	mov rax, 1      ; exit command to kernel
	int 0x80        ; interrupt 80 hex, call kernel to exit process
 
_my_func:           ; our function
	mov rbx, rdi    ; arg1, file descriptor (stdout)
	mov rcx, rsi    ; arg2, pointer to string
; mov rdx, rdx      ; arg3, length of string to print
 
	mov rax, 4      ; sys_write syscall number
	int 0x80        ; fire system call
	ret
function call using syscall instruction
SECTION .text      ; code section
 
global _start      ; make label available to linker
_start:            ; standard entry point
	mov rdi, 1     ; arg1, file descriptor (stdout)
	mov rsi, msg   ; arg2, pointer to string
	mov rdx, len   ; arg3, length of string to print
	call _my_func  ; push raddr on stack and jump to label my_func
 
	mov rbx, 0     ; exit code, 0=normal
	mov rax, 1     ; exit command to kernel
	int 0x80       ; interrupt 80 hex, call kernel to exit process
 
_my_func:          ; our function
	mov rax, 1     ; sys_write syscall number = 1 => 64 bit interface
syscall            ; fast system call => faster than int 0x80
ret
function call using stack frames
SECTION .text       ; code section
 
global _start       ; make label available to linker
_start:             ; standard entry point
	push 1          ; arg1, file descriptor (stdout)
	push msg        ; arg2, pointer to string
	push len        ; arg3, length of string to print
	call _my_func   ; push raddr on stack and jump to label my_func
 
	mov rbx, 0      ; exit code, 0=normal
	mov rax, 1      ; exit command to kernel
	int 0x80        ; interrupt 80 hex, call kernel to **exit** process
	
_my_func:                  ; our function
	push rbp               ; save stack frame pointer
	mov rsp, rbp           ; set rsp to new stackframe
	mov rbx, [rbp + 32]    ; arg1, file descriptor (stdout)
	mov rcx, [rbp + 24]    ; arg2, pointer to string
	mov rdx, [rbp + 32]    ; arg3, length of string to print
	mov rax, 4             ; sys_write syscall number
	int 0x80         ; fire system call
	
	pop rbp          ; save stack frame pointer
	ret 24           ; remove params and return by popping return addres

This is not used in x86_64 but was used in IA32 (32 Bit protected mode)

for-Loop

for (int i=0; i<10; i++);

	xor rcx, rcx  ; set counter = 0
 
L0:
	cmp rcx, 10    ; compare counter with 10
	jge L1.        ; leave loop if rcx >=10
 
	...            ; loop body
 
	inc rcx        ; rcx++
	jmp L0.        ;jump back for next iteration
 
L1:
loop

using loop instruction

	mov rcx, 10   ; set counter = 10
L0:               
                  
	...           ; loop body
	loop L0       ; jump back for next iteration
 
L1:

rechnerarchitektur/assembly/x86.title: x86
rechnerarchitektur/assembly/x86.content:
Sections

separation of code and data is not needed (von-Neumann)
creating of section for the respective logical areas

SECTION .data
; global data
SECTION .bss
; uninitialized global data
SECTION .text
; provides code
Data Types

The base is a word (16 bit).

SECTION .data
	MyByte DB 0 ; Define one byte (8 bit)
	MyWord DW 0 ; Define one word (16 bit)
	MyDword DD 0 ; Define one double word (32 bit)
	MyQword DQ 0 ; Define one quad word (64 bit)
How are the data types located in memory

Little vs Big Endian
Little Endian: The leas significant byte first \Rightarrow used in x86 architecture

‚ÄúUnintuitiv ‚Äî Andersrum als erwartet‚Äù
Example DEADBEEF





























Adress [Byte]0123Little EndianE FB EA DD EBig EndianD EA DB EE F
Arrays and strings

A string is an array of bytes (0 terminated)

SECTION .data
	Str DB "I am a string!", 13, 10, 0
	Character DB "A"
uninitialized arrrays

in BSS section

in principle, (uninitialized) array con be defined in every section



SECTION .data
	array TIMES 1024 DB 0; initialized array
SECTION .bss
	var RESB 1 ;1 element of type "Byte
	array2 RESB 2048 ; 2048 elements of type "Byte"
	feld RESD 1024 ;1024 elements of type "Doubleword"```
Import / export of symbols

Symbol is a marker / an address within the data / code section
can be defined in one file and used by another file

;define that printf is defined in another module
extern printf
;define errno as symbol, which can be used by another module
global errno
 
SECTION .data
	errno DW 0
Function call ‚Äî Hello World

Register mapping for system calls using int 0x80

Developed for 32 (but in 64 bit long mode)
register mapping for system call invocation using int 0x80:






































system call number1st parameter2nd parameter3rd paramter4th5th6thresulteaxebxecxedxesiediebpeax![[x86 examples#hello-woldHello Wold]]
nasm -f elf64 hello.asm
ld -m elf_x86_64 hello.o ‚Äìo hello
./hello
Stack
; store data from rdx on the stack
push rdx
 
;do something
 
;restore data
pop rdx
Memory layout

RSP points always to the top of the stack
The stack grows from the high address to the low address
The heap grow from low address to high address

Function call ‚Äî using syscall

different to function call using 0x80 (register mapping)
syscall uses x86_64 ABI, so all parameters are already in the right registers
Register mapping using syscall
c calling convention


























system call number1st parameter2nd parameter3rd parameter4th parameter5th6thresultraxrdirsirdxr10r8r9rax

Transclude of x86-examples#function-call-using-syscall-instruction
See wiki assembly interface

RFLAGS Register

CF, ZF are used for unsigned conditional jump
SF, OF, ZF are used for signed conditional jump


Jumps
Unsigned conditional jumps



































cmp a, bMnemonicFlagsDescriptiona-b>0JA / JNBECF=0 and ZF=0above / not below nor equala-b\ge0JAE / JNBCF=0above or equal / not belowa-b<0JB / JNAECF=1below / not above  nor equala-b\le0JBE / JNACF=1 or ZF=1below or equal / not above
target: ...
	sub rax, 1
	cmp rax, 1
	jae target
Signed conditional jump



































cmp a, bMnemonicFlagsDescriptiona-b>0JG / JNLE((SF xor OF) or ZF) = 0greater / not less nor equala-b >=0JGE / JNL(SF xor OF) = 0greater or equal / not lessa-b<0JL / JNGE(SF xor OF) = 1less / not greater or equala-b\le0JLE / JNG((SF xor OF) or ZF) = 1less or equal / not greater
target: ...
	sub rax, 1
	cmp rax, 1
	jge target
Loop

example without loop instruction
loop decrements rcx, checks for 0 if rcx is 0, terminates the loop

otherwise continues
Transclude of x86-examples#loop
